newsitem.title: FRANCE: French beet crop benefits from rain, more needed.
newsitem.headline: French beet crop benefits from rain, more needed.

text.p: Rains last week brought much-needed relief to France's sugar beets but farmers said more rainfall was needed over the next two weeks following a three-month dry spell.
"Last week's rain has been good for beet growth. All we need is more rain over the next 15 days," an analyst for the French sugar beet planters federation CGB told Reuters.
The rain helped speed up crop development that had been hampered by dry conditions.
"Most of the crop has now reached above ground-development," the analyst said.
On April 25 only 40 percent of the beets sown had reached that stage.
Last week's rains were followed by dry and warm conditions by mid-week. But scattered showers returned to western regions on Saturday and substantial rain was forecast across France for Monday.
Meteo France has predicted the rain may last until mid-week.
The analyst said that at this stage, yield potential was intact but stressed it was premature to make an estimate.
"All I can say is that there are no elements that could threaten yield potential," he said.
National sugar intervention board FIRS expects France to produce 4.20 million tonnes of beet sugar in 1997/98 against 4.226 million in 1996/97, mostly as a result of lower sowings.
